title: 114_hr540
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fifth Amendment Integrity Restoration Act of 2015" or the "FAIR Act". Civil forfeiture proceedings are addressed in the Act. Section 983 of title 18, United States Code is amended to modify procedures for civil forfeiture, including changes to evidence standards and government's theory of forfeiture. The amendment to Section 983 of title 18, United States Code modifies procedures for civil forfeiture, including changes to evidence standards and the government's theory of forfeiture. The amendment requires the government to establish a substantial connection between the seized property and the criminal offense, as well as prove that the owner used the property to facilitate the offense or knowingly consented to its use in connection with the offense. The amendment to Section 983 of title 18, United States Code modifies procedures for civil forfeiture, including changes to evidence standards and the government's theory of forfeiture. Specifically, it requires the government to establish a substantial connection between the seized property and the criminal offense, as well as prove that the owner used the property to facilitate the offense or knowingly consented to its use in connection with the offense. Additionally, it amends subsection (d)(2)(A) by specifying the actions of an owner upon learning about the offense. Revisions to Controlled Substances Act include striking certain paragraphs and redesignating others. Revisions to Title 18 of the United States Code involve striking specific paragraphs and redesignating others, including forwarding forfeited property proceeds to the Treasurer of the United States. Revisions to Title 18 of the United States Code involve redesignating paragraphs and removing specific sentences related to the transfer of forfeited property proceeds to the Treasury. The Tariff Act of 1930 is amended by removing specific subparagraphs and sentences related to payments and transfers of forfeited property proceeds. This includes striking subsection headings, subsections, and redesignating subparagraphs and paragraphs in Title 31 of the United States Code. The Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to remove specific subparagraphs related to forfeited property proceeds. Section 524(c)(4) of title 28, United States Code, is also amended to restructure asset forfeiture fund deposits. Additionally, structuring transactions to evade reporting requirements is prohibited. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code include inserting "knowingly" in various subsections and adding language regarding funds not derived from a legitimate source. Section 5317 is amended to include a probable cause hearing in connection with property seizures related to certain monetary instruments transactions. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code include adding a probable cause hearing requirement for property seizures related to certain monetary transactions under section 5324. A court must conduct a hearing within 14 days of notice and return the seized property unless probable cause of a violation is found. The amendment requires notification of the right to a hearing for property seizures under section 5324. It applies to property seized after the Act's enactment date. SEC. 6. PROPORTIONALITY. Amends factors considered in determining forfeiture, including seriousness of offense, nexus of property to offense, available sentences, property value, and hardship to owner and dependents. SEC. 7. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. Amends reporting requirements for funds obtained from criminal and civil forfeitures. SEC. 8. APPLICABILITY. The amendments made by this Act apply to civil forfeiture proceedings pending or filed on or after the enactment date, and to amounts received from property forfeiture after the enactment date.
